Graph Federated Learning with Hidden Representation Sharing

Shuang Wu
UCLA
shuangwu222@ucla.edu&Mingxuan Zhang11footnotemark: 1
Purdue University

Abstract

Learning on Graphs (LoG) is widely used in multi-client systems when each client has insufficient local data, and multiple clients have to share their raw data to learn a model of good quality. One scenario is to recommend items to clients with limited historical data and sharing similar preferences with other clients in a social network. On the other hand, due to the increasing demands for the protection of clients’ data privacy, Federated Learning (FL) has been widely adopted: FL requires models to be trained in a multi-client system and restricts sharing of raw data among clients. The underlying potential data-sharing conflict between LoG and FL is under-explored and how to benefit from both sides is a promising problem. In this work, we first formulate the Graph Federated Learning (GFL) problem that unifies LoG and FL in multi-client systems and then propose sharing hidden representation instead of the raw data of neighbors to protect data privacy as a solution. To overcome the biased gradient problem in GFL, we provide a gradient estimation method and its convergence analysis under the non-convex objective. In experiments, we evaluate our method in classification tasks on graphs. Our experiment shows a good match between our theory and the practice.

1 Introduction

Learning on Graphs (LoG) in multi-client systems has extensive applications such as Graph Neural Networks (GNNs) for recommendation [1, 2, 3, 4], finance [5, 6], and traffic [7, 8]. The key to the success of LoG is sharing local raw data between clients. For example, when recommending items to users with insufficient local data, data sharing from their friends with similar preferences in a social network can improve the performance of recommendation models. On the other hand, Federated Learning (FL) is widely explored due to its protection of data privacy, especially in medical fields [9], mobile device fields [10, 11], and Internet of Things (IoT) fields [12]. In FL, models are trained without data sharing among clients to protect clients’ local data privacy. As a consequence, combining FL and LoG in multi-client systems faces a fundamental conflict in data sharing.

As we know, considerable works are combing Federated Learning and Graph Machine Learning. One attractive research line is using FL to train GNNs [13, 14]. In addition, [15, 4] use FL to train GNN-based models to address specific real-world applications. [16, 17] summarises current efforts on FL over graphs, including the above literature. However, most current works did not utilize the network of clients in the system and failed to protect the privacy of the nodes in the network. In other words, previous literature never models FL clients as nodes in GNNs on multi-client systems. Besides, all these works are application-oriented without a theoretical guarantee. Therefore, fundamental data sharing conflict remains unsolved.

Such significant conflict motivates our investigation of the construction of Graph Federated Learning (GFL) in multi-client systems: Can we formulate a GFL framework to address the data sharing conflict, paired with theoretical and empirical supports? We aim to deliver a generic framework of GFL. Our work focuses on the centralized federated learning setting while data collected by clients are Non-IID distributed.

Contributions. We formulate the GFL problem for a graph-based model in multi-client systems. To address the data sharing conflict, we propose an FL solution with the hidden representation sharing technique, which only requires the sharing of hidden representations rather than the raw data from the neighbors to protect data privacy on multi-client systems. A technical challenge arises since the hidden representations are only exchanged during communication between clients and the central server, making unbiased gradient estimation becomes impractical. As a remedy, we provide a practical gradient estimation method. Moreover, a convergence analysis with non-convex objectives of the proposed algorithm is provided. To the best of our knowledge, this is the first theoretical analysis for FL with a graph-based model. We propose GFL-APPNP and empirically evaluate the proposed method for several classification tasks on graphs, including deterministic node classification, stochastic node classification, and supervised classification. Our experiments show that the proposed method converges and achieves competitive performance. Additionally, the results provide a good match between our theory and practice. The contributions in this paper are summarized as follows:

  • •

    Formulate the GFL problem to model FL clients as nodes in LoG on multi-client systems.

  • •

    Propose FL solution with hidden representation sharing for GFL problem to resolve data sharing conflict.

  • •

    Provide theoretical non-convex convergence analysis for GFL.

  • •

    Propose GFL-APPNP and empirically show the proposed algorithm is valid and has competitive performance on classification tasks.

2 Related Works

Federated Learning for GNNs. How to utilize the FL technique to train GNNs is an interesting topic that attracts lots of attention from researchers. For instance, [13] focuses on graph semi-supervised learning via meta-learning and handles testing nodes with new label domains as well as leverages unlabeled data. [14] proposes federated learning to train GNNs by dividing a large graph into subgraphs. [18] considers an FL solution to train GNNs for the entire graph classification. [19] proposes decentralized periodic SGD to solve the serverless Federated Multi-Task Learning for GNNs. [15] Proposes a GNN-based federated learning architecture for spatio-temporal data modeling. [4] puts forward a decentralized federated framework for privacy-preserving GNN-based recommendations. However, [14, 13, 18, 17] assume each client has its own graphs and [15, 4] use federated learning to train GNN-based model. None of these works is federated learning to train GNNs on multi-client systems with the protection of node-level privacy, which is addressed by our work.

Personalized Federated Learning. The conventional FL approach faces a fundamental challenge of poor performance on highly heterogeneous clients. Previous works [20, 21] provided solutions to tackling Non-IID data across clients. Recently, inspired by personalization, research on personalized federated learning has developed rapidly [22, 23, 24]. Particularly, personalization with graph structure to tackle heterogeneity in FL is highly related to our work. For example, [25] proposes MOCHA which uses a graph-type regularization to control the parameters and perform a prime-dual framework, and [26] provides a similar regularizer to the multitask learning. [23] considers an implicit model where personalized parameters come from a Moreau envelope, and this idea recently has got generalized to graph Laplacian regularization [27]. [28, 29] assumes that there is a common parameter shared across the network when each node of the graph is viewed as a federated learning client that generates independent data. All these works are model-level personalization based on graphs, such as graph regularization, while LoG encourages data-level sharing.

Notations. Let [n]delimited-[]𝑛[n] be the set {1,2,…,n}12…𝑛\{1,2,...,n\}. Vectors are assumed to be column vectors. 𝟏1{\boldsymbol{1}} is a vector with all ones. 𝑰𝑰{\boldsymbol{I}} is the identity matrix with appropriate dimension. ∥⋅∥norm⋅\norm{\cdot} is assumed to be the 222-norm. For a matrix 𝑨𝑨{\boldsymbol{A}}, λm​a​x​(𝑨)subscript𝜆𝑚𝑎𝑥𝑨\lambda_{max}({\boldsymbol{A}}) is the maximum eigenvalue of 𝑨𝑨{\boldsymbol{A}} and 𝑨†superscript𝑨†{\boldsymbol{A}}^{\dagger} is the Moore–Penrose inverse of 𝑨𝑨{\boldsymbol{A}}. 𝒪​(⋅)𝒪⋅{\cal O}(\cdot) is the big-O notation.

3 Graph Federated Learning

3.1 Preliminaries

Federated Learning. In typical FL, multiple clients collectively solve a global task. Our work focuses on the centralized setting with a central server, and we consider the following consensus optimization problem:

min𝑾⁡ ​F​(𝑾):=1N​∑k=1NFk​(𝑾)assignsubscript𝑾 𝐹𝑾1𝑁superscriptsubscript𝑘1𝑁subscript𝐹𝑘𝑾\displaystyle\min_{{\boldsymbol{W}}}\mbox{ }F({\boldsymbol{W}}):=\frac{1}{N}\sum_{k=1}^{N}F_{k}({\boldsymbol{W}}) (1)

where N𝑁N is the number of clients, and 𝑾𝑾{\boldsymbol{W}} is the model parameter. F​(𝑾)𝐹𝑾F({\boldsymbol{W}}) is the global loss function and Fk​(𝑾)subscript𝐹𝑘𝑾F_{k}({\boldsymbol{W}}) is the local loss function. For client k𝑘k, it has access only to its local data and conducts local update 𝑾kt+1←𝑾kt−η​𝒈kt←superscriptsubscript𝑾𝑘𝑡1superscriptsubscript𝑾𝑘𝑡𝜂subscriptsuperscript𝒈𝑡𝑘{\boldsymbol{W}}_{k}^{t+1}\leftarrow{\boldsymbol{W}}_{k}^{t}-\eta{\boldsymbol{g}}^{t}_{k} where 𝒈kt:=∇F^k​(𝑾kt)assignsubscriptsuperscript𝒈𝑡𝑘∇subscript^𝐹𝑘superscriptsubscript𝑾𝑘𝑡{\boldsymbol{g}}^{t}_{k}:=\nabla\hat{F}_{k}({\boldsymbol{W}}_{k}^{t}) is the stochastic gradient estimator of ∇Fk​(𝑾kt)∇subscript𝐹𝑘superscriptsubscript𝑾𝑘𝑡\nabla F_{k}({\boldsymbol{W}}_{k}^{t}) and η𝜂\eta is the learning rate. Throughout our work, ∇∇\nabla is gradient w.r.t model parameter 𝑾𝑾{\boldsymbol{W}}. Denote I𝐼I as the number of local updates between two communication rounds. During the FL process, after I𝐼I steps of local update, the central server aggregates the latest models from clients according to FedAvg [30]: 𝑾¯t=1N​∑k=1N𝑾ktsuperscript¯𝑾𝑡1𝑁superscriptsubscript𝑘1𝑁superscriptsubscript𝑾𝑘𝑡\bar{{\boldsymbol{W}}}^{t}=\frac{1}{N}\sum_{k=1}^{N}{\boldsymbol{W}}_{k}^{t}.

Statistical Heterogeneity. The goal of FL is to minimize the global loss on the average data distribution across clients, as shown in Eq.(1). However, in most substantial applications of FL, clients collect data in a Non-IID distributed manner, leading to a fundamental statistical heterogeneity/shift problem in FL [21, 31]. [22, 32] have suggested quantification of statistical heterogeneity. In this paper, we use the term "level of statistical heterogeneity" to describe how large the statistical shift is across clients.

3.2 GFL Problem Formulation

The topological structure which describes the Non-IID relationship among clients’ distributions is an undirected graph denoted as 𝒢=(𝒱,ℰ)𝒢𝒱ℰ{\cal G}=({\cal V},{\cal E}) where 𝒱𝒱{\cal V} is a set of N𝑁N clients and ℰℰ{\cal E} is a set of edges. The adjacency matrix of 𝒢𝒢{\cal G} is denoted as 𝑨∈{0,1}N×N𝑨superscript01𝑁𝑁{\boldsymbol{A}}\in\{0,1\}^{N\times N}. Throughout this paper, nodes in graph 𝒢𝒢{\cal G} are referred to as clients. Furthermore, denote 𝚵𝒢=(𝑿,𝒀)∈𝑹N×(d+c)subscript𝚵𝒢𝑿𝒀superscript𝑹𝑁𝑑𝑐{\boldsymbol{\Xi}}_{{\cal G}}=({\boldsymbol{X}},{\boldsymbol{Y}})\in{\boldsymbol{R}}^{N\times(d+c)} as the data matrix where 𝑿∈ℝN×d𝑿superscriptℝ𝑁𝑑{\boldsymbol{X}}\in\mathbb{R}^{N\times d} is the feature matrix with the number of features d𝑑d and 𝒀∈ℝN×c𝒀superscriptℝ𝑁𝑐{\boldsymbol{Y}}\in\mathbb{R}^{N\times c} is the label matrix with the dimension of label c𝑐c. To formulate the GFL problem generally, consider 𝚵𝒢subscript𝚵𝒢{\boldsymbol{\Xi}}_{{\cal G}} as a random matrix from a distribution 𝒟𝒢subscript𝒟𝒢{\cal D}_{{\cal G}} which depends on 𝒢𝒢{\cal G}, that is, 𝚵𝒢∼𝒟𝒢similar-tosubscript𝚵𝒢subscript𝒟𝒢{\boldsymbol{\Xi}}_{{\cal G}}\sim{\cal D}_{{\cal G}}. More specifically, we define the k𝑘k-th row vector of 𝚵𝒢subscript𝚵𝒢{\boldsymbol{\Xi}}_{{\cal G}} as 𝝃k:=(𝒙k,𝒚k)assignsubscript𝝃𝑘subscript𝒙𝑘subscript𝒚𝑘{\boldsymbol{\xi}}_{k}:=({\boldsymbol{x}}_{k},{\boldsymbol{y}}_{k}) where 𝒙ksubscript𝒙𝑘{\boldsymbol{x}}_{k} is the feature vector and 𝒚ksubscript𝒚𝑘{\boldsymbol{y}}_{k} is a vector of labels in client k𝑘k. Thus 𝚵𝒢subscript𝚵𝒢{\boldsymbol{\Xi}}_{{\cal G}} is the random data matrix whose rows are correlated, and the relationship between 𝝃ksubscript𝝃𝑘{\boldsymbol{\xi}}_{k} is described by graph 𝒢𝒢{\cal G}. Here we assume that graph structure 𝒢𝒢{\cal G} is deterministic. With these notations, the GFL problem is defined as:

min𝑾⁡ ​1N​∑k=1NFk​(𝑾),where ​Fk​(𝑾):=𝔼​[fk​(𝑾;𝚵𝒢)],assignsubscript𝑾 1𝑁superscriptsubscript𝑘1𝑁subscript𝐹𝑘𝑾where subscript𝐹𝑘𝑾𝔼delimited-[]subscript𝑓𝑘𝑾subscript𝚵𝒢\displaystyle\min_{{\boldsymbol{W}}}\mbox{ }\frac{1}{N}\sum_{k=1}^{N}F_{k}({\boldsymbol{W}}),\text{where }F_{k}({\boldsymbol{W}}):=\mathbb{E}[f_{k}({\boldsymbol{W}};{\boldsymbol{\Xi}}_{{\cal G}})], (2)

and fk​(𝑾;𝚵𝒢)subscript𝑓𝑘𝑾subscript𝚵𝒢f_{k}({\boldsymbol{W}};{\boldsymbol{\Xi}}_{{\cal G}}) is the local loss after observing data matrix 𝚵𝒢subscript𝚵𝒢{\boldsymbol{\Xi}}_{{\cal G}}, indicating the local objective function of client k𝑘k depends not only on the data collected by the k𝑘k-th client but also the data from other clients. This is the key difference between GFL and conventional FL. As our discussion in §§\S1, this crucial difference induces the data-sharing conflict. Therefore, we propose the following hidden representation sharing method to address the challenge of data-sharing conflict in the GFL problem.

3.3 Hidden Representation Sharing

Our proposal is using hidden representation. The hidden representations are allowed to be shared across clients in network 𝒢𝒢{\cal G}, and a neighborhood aggregator is applied to these hidden representations of all nodes. For client k𝑘k, define its hidden representation 𝒉ksubscript𝒉𝑘{\boldsymbol{h}}_{k} as follow

𝒉ksubscript𝒉𝑘\displaystyle{\boldsymbol{h}}_{k} =Ψh​(𝒙k;𝑾h)absentsubscriptΨℎsubscript𝒙𝑘subscript𝑾ℎ\displaystyle=\Psi_{h}({\boldsymbol{x}}_{k};{\boldsymbol{W}}_{h}) (3)

where Ψh​(⋅;𝑾h)subscriptΨℎ⋅subscript𝑾ℎ\Psi_{h}(\cdot;{\boldsymbol{W}}_{h}) is a hidden encoder such as the multi-layer perceptron (MLP) parametrized by 𝑾hsubscript𝑾ℎ{\boldsymbol{W}}_{h}. The hidden representation matrix is denoted as 𝑯∈ℝN×dh𝑯superscriptℝ𝑁subscript𝑑ℎ{\boldsymbol{H}}\in\mathbb{R}^{N\times d_{h}} where the k𝑘k-th row vector of 𝑯𝑯{\boldsymbol{H}} is 𝒉ksubscript𝒉𝑘{\boldsymbol{h}}_{k} and dhsubscript𝑑ℎd_{h} is the dimension of the hidden representations. Graph representations are defined by neighborhood representation aggregation of 𝑯𝑯{\boldsymbol{H}}:

𝒁𝒁\displaystyle{\boldsymbol{Z}} =Ψ𝒢​(𝑯;𝑾𝒢)absentsubscriptΨ𝒢𝑯subscript𝑾𝒢\displaystyle=\Psi_{{\cal G}}({\boldsymbol{H}};{\boldsymbol{W}}_{{\cal G}}) (4)

where Ψ𝒢​(⋅;𝑾𝒢)subscriptΨ𝒢⋅subscript𝑾𝒢\Psi_{{\cal G}}(\cdot;{\boldsymbol{W}}_{{\cal G}}) is a neighborhood aggregator parametrized by 𝑾𝒢subscript𝑾𝒢{\boldsymbol{W}}_{{\cal G}}. 𝒁∈ℝN×dz𝒁superscriptℝ𝑁subscript𝑑𝑧{\boldsymbol{Z}}\in\mathbb{R}^{N\times d_{z}} is the graph representation matrix whose k𝑘k-th row vector is denoted as 𝒛ksubscript𝒛𝑘{\boldsymbol{z}}_{k} and dzsubscript𝑑𝑧d_{z} is the dimension of the graph representations. In most classification tasks, dz=csubscript𝑑𝑧𝑐d_{z}=c. Model parameter 𝑾=(𝑾h,𝑾𝒢)⊤𝑾superscriptsubscript𝑾ℎsubscript𝑾𝒢top{\boldsymbol{W}}=({\boldsymbol{W}}_{h},{\boldsymbol{W}}_{{\cal G}})^{\top} is the concatenate of 𝑾hsubscript𝑾ℎ{\boldsymbol{W}}_{h} and 𝑾𝒢subscript𝑾𝒢{\boldsymbol{W}}_{{\cal G}}. With these privacy-preserving representations, the loss function for the corresponding graph federated optimization can be expressed as, fk​(𝑾;𝚵𝒢):=ℓ​(𝒚k,𝒛k)assignsubscript𝑓𝑘𝑾subscript𝚵𝒢ℓsubscript𝒚𝑘subscript𝒛𝑘f_{k}({\boldsymbol{W}};{\boldsymbol{\Xi}}_{{\cal G}}):=\ell({\boldsymbol{y}}_{k},{\boldsymbol{z}}_{k}) where ℓℓ\ell is the pre-specified loss function such as cross-entropy for classification task.

Remark 1.

The explication in Figure 1 shows that the hidden encoder is a global model which facilitates the involvement of FL, while the neighborhood aggregator is the personalized model which accounts for statistical heterogeneity. Intuitively, ΨhsubscriptΨℎ\Psi_{h} contributes to privacy protection and representation extraction. Meanwhile, Ψ𝒢subscriptΨ𝒢\Psi_{{\cal G}} serves as modeling the heterogeneity using graph 𝒢𝒢{\cal G}. Note that if we set Ψ𝒢subscriptΨ𝒢\Psi_{{\cal G}} as the identity mapping (ignore the graph information), our solution reduces to the conventional FL solution to learn a global model ΨhsubscriptΨℎ\Psi_{h}. In addition, when 𝒢𝒢{\cal G} does not fully capture the relationship across clients, 𝐖𝒢subscript𝐖𝒢{\boldsymbol{W}}_{{\cal G}} serves as weights for adjusting the neighborhood aggregation level using 𝒢𝒢{\cal G}. See Appendix C.3 for further discussion.

3.4 Gradient Estimation

In practice, to solve the GFL problem by gradient-based methods, the unbiased stochastic gradient ∇fk​(𝑾;𝚵𝒢)∇subscript𝑓𝑘𝑾subscript𝚵𝒢\nabla f_{k}({\boldsymbol{W}};{\boldsymbol{\Xi}}_{{\cal G}}) of client k𝑘k depends on data from all nodes in the network 𝒢𝒢{\cal G} (𝔼​[fk​(𝑾;𝚵𝒢)]=Fk​(𝑾)𝔼delimited-[]subscript𝑓𝑘𝑾subscript𝚵𝒢subscript𝐹𝑘𝑾\mathbb{E}[f_{k}({\boldsymbol{W}};{\boldsymbol{\Xi}}_{{\cal G}})]=F_{k}({\boldsymbol{W}})). However, since FL restricts the data-sharing, ∇fk​(𝑾;𝚵𝒢)∇subscript𝑓𝑘𝑾subscript𝚵𝒢\nabla f_{k}({\boldsymbol{W}};{\boldsymbol{\Xi}}_{{\cal G}}) is inaccessible. Another estimation of ∇Fk​(𝑾)∇subscript𝐹𝑘𝑾\nabla F_{k}({\boldsymbol{W}}) for local updates must be raised. In the proposed hidden representation sharing method, local information is exchanged as a function of {𝒉j,∇𝒉j}j=1Nsuperscriptsubscriptsubscript𝒉𝑗∇subscript𝒉𝑗𝑗1𝑁\{{\boldsymbol{h}}_{j},\nabla{\boldsymbol{h}}_{j}\}_{j=1}^{N} during the interactions between clients and the central server. In other words, if the client k𝑘k can access {𝒉j,∇𝒉j}j=1Nsuperscriptsubscriptsubscript𝒉𝑗∇subscript𝒉𝑗𝑗1𝑁\{{\boldsymbol{h}}_{j},\nabla{\boldsymbol{h}}_{j}\}_{j=1}^{N}, the unbiased estimator ∇fk​(𝑾;𝚵𝒢)∇subscript𝑓𝑘𝑾subscript𝚵𝒢\nabla f_{k}({\boldsymbol{W}};{\boldsymbol{\Xi}}_{{\cal G}}) is accessible. Formally, with the shared hidden representations, ∇fk​(𝑾;𝚵𝒢)∇subscript𝑓𝑘𝑾subscript𝚵𝒢\nabla f_{k}({\boldsymbol{W}};{\boldsymbol{\Xi}}_{{\cal G}}) can be expressed as a function of hidden representations: ∇fk​(𝑾;𝚵𝒢)=ϕk​(𝒉1,…,𝒉N)∇subscript𝑓𝑘𝑾subscript𝚵𝒢subscriptitalic-ϕ𝑘subscript𝒉1…subscript𝒉𝑁\nabla f_{k}({\boldsymbol{W}};{\boldsymbol{\Xi}}_{{\cal G}})=\phi_{k}({\boldsymbol{h}}_{1},...,{\boldsymbol{h}}_{N}). Note that ∇𝒉j∇subscript𝒉𝑗\nabla{\boldsymbol{h}}_{j} is also a function of 𝒉jsubscript𝒉𝑗{\boldsymbol{h}}_{j}, and we consider the case that estimating ∇𝒉j∇subscript𝒉𝑗\nabla{\boldsymbol{h}}_{j} is completely based on an estimator of 𝒉jsubscript𝒉𝑗{\boldsymbol{h}}_{j}. Furthermore, define 𝒉^j→ksubscript^𝒉→𝑗𝑘\hat{{\boldsymbol{h}}}_{j\rightarrow k} as the estimation of the hidden representation 𝒉jsubscript𝒉𝑗{\boldsymbol{h}}_{j} for client k𝑘k. Then the biased estimator of ∇Fk​(𝑾)∇subscript𝐹𝑘𝑾\nabla F_{k}({\boldsymbol{W}}) is,

∇f^k​(𝑾;𝝃k)=ϕk​(𝒉^1→k,…,𝒉^N→k)​, ​∀k∈[N].∇subscript^𝑓𝑘𝑾subscript𝝃𝑘subscriptitalic-ϕ𝑘subscript^𝒉→1𝑘…subscript^𝒉→𝑁𝑘, for-all𝑘delimited-[]𝑁\displaystyle\nabla\hat{f}_{k}({\boldsymbol{W}};{\boldsymbol{\xi}}_{k})=\phi_{k}(\hat{{\boldsymbol{h}}}_{1\rightarrow k},...,\hat{{\boldsymbol{h}}}_{N\rightarrow k})\mbox{, }\forall k\in[N]. (5)

The strategy to design estimator 𝒉^j→ksubscript^𝒉→𝑗𝑘\hat{{\boldsymbol{h}}}_{j\rightarrow k} depends on the concrete scenario. In §§\S5, we provide a gradient compensation strategy with theoretical analysis in Appendix C.1 and the empirical results of this biased estimation strategy are provided in §§\S6. In practice, the estimator of ∇Fk​(𝑾)∇subscript𝐹𝑘𝑾\nabla F_{k}({\boldsymbol{W}}) is the batch mean of biased stochastic gradients. Formally, suppose ℬk:={𝝃k,s}s=1|ℬk|assignsubscriptℬ𝑘superscriptsubscriptsubscript𝝃𝑘𝑠𝑠1subscriptℬ𝑘{\cal B}_{k}:=\{{\boldsymbol{\xi}}_{k,s}\}_{s=1}^{|{\cal B}_{k}|} is the mini-batch with batch size |ℬk|subscriptℬ𝑘|{\cal B}_{k}| for some local update in client k𝑘k. ∇f^k​(𝑾;𝝃k,s)∇subscript^𝑓𝑘𝑾subscript𝝃𝑘𝑠\nabla\hat{f}_{k}({\boldsymbol{W}};{\boldsymbol{\xi}}_{k,s}) is the estimated gradient which depends on the example 𝝃k,ssubscript𝝃𝑘𝑠{\boldsymbol{\xi}}_{k,s}. The batch mean of biased stochastic gradients is defined as ∇F^k​(𝑾):=1|ℬk|​∑s∈ℬk∇f^k​(𝑾;𝝃k,s)assign∇subscript^𝐹𝑘𝑾1subscriptℬ𝑘subscript𝑠subscriptℬ𝑘∇subscript^𝑓𝑘𝑾subscript𝝃𝑘𝑠\nabla\hat{F}_{k}({\boldsymbol{W}}):=\frac{1}{|{\cal B}_{k}|}\sum_{s\in{\cal B}_{k}}\nabla\hat{f}_{k}({\boldsymbol{W}};{\boldsymbol{\xi}}_{k,s}).

Privacy in GFL. FL and GFL require the protection of node-level privacy: client can not share their own collected data with both other clients and the central server directly. However, directly sharing {𝒉j,∇𝒉j}j=1Nsuperscriptsubscriptsubscript𝒉𝑗∇subscript𝒉𝑗𝑗1𝑁\{{\boldsymbol{h}}_{j},\nabla{\boldsymbol{h}}_{j}\}_{j=1}^{N} raises the concern about raw data recovery by untrustworthy clients or the central server. Our proposed solution does not violate node-level privacy even though we allow sharing hidden representations and the corresponding gradients during the communication between clients and the central server. By using the personalized neighborhood aggregator, clients will not receive {𝒉j,∇𝒉j}j=1Nsuperscriptsubscriptsubscript𝒉𝑗∇subscript𝒉𝑗𝑗1𝑁\{{\boldsymbol{h}}_{j},\nabla{\boldsymbol{h}}_{j}\}_{j=1}^{N} directly, making the raw data recovery infeasible. In addition, the concern about the unreliable server can be addressed by applying Differential Privacy (DP) method in GFL. Detailed discussion and experiments for DP are given in Appendix C.4 and Appendix D.4.4

3.5 Graph Federated Learning Procedure

A framework of communications in GFL with hidden representation sharing is described in Figure 1. An concrete example is Algorithm 1 introduced in §§\S 5.2. Steps at each communication round are:

  • (1)

    Uploading Models: Clients parallelly upload the latest models to the central server.

  • (2)

    Centralizing Models: Central server aggregates models by FedAvg and broadcasts the aggregated result.

  • (3)

    Uploading Hidden Representations: Clients compute estimated hidden representation and their gradient using the received aggregated model in step (2) and then parallelly upload them to the central server.

  • (4)

    Broadcasting Hidden Representations: Central server allocates estimated hidden representation and their gradients and broadcasts the aggregated ones to clients.

  • (5)

    Local Updates: Clients parallelly perform local updates for I𝐼I times.

4 Theoretical Analysis

4.1 Assumptions

Assumption 1.

(Smoothness) Local loss function Fksubscript𝐹𝑘F_{k} is differentiable and assumed to be smooth with constant ρfsubscript𝜌𝑓\rho_{f}, ∀k∈[N]for-all𝑘delimited-[]𝑁\forall k\in[N]. Formally, ∀𝐖,𝐖′for-all𝐖superscript𝐖′\forall{\boldsymbol{W}},{\boldsymbol{W}}^{\prime}, ∃ρf>0subscript𝜌𝑓0\exists\rho_{f}>0 such that ‖∇Fk​(𝐖)−∇Fk​(𝐖′)‖≤ρf​‖𝐖−𝐖′‖norm∇subscript𝐹𝑘𝐖∇subscript𝐹𝑘superscript𝐖′subscript𝜌𝑓norm𝐖superscript𝐖′\norm{\nabla F_{k}({\boldsymbol{W}})-\nabla F_{k}({\boldsymbol{W}}^{\prime})}\leq\rho_{f}\norm{{\boldsymbol{W}}-{\boldsymbol{W}}^{\prime}}.

Assumption 2.

(Bound for Hidden Representation Estimation) Hidden Representation 𝐡jsubscript𝐡𝑗{\boldsymbol{h}}_{j} of client j𝑗j is estimated by 𝐡^j→ksubscript^𝐡→𝑗𝑘\hat{{\boldsymbol{h}}}_{j\rightarrow k} for local updates at client k𝑘k. The mean squared error of estimation is bounded in the following sense: ∀j,k∈[N]for-all𝑗𝑘delimited-[]𝑁\forall j,k\in[N], ∃σj2>0superscriptsubscript𝜎𝑗20\exists\sigma_{j}^{2}>0 and σH2:=∑j=1Nσj2assignsuperscriptsubscript𝜎𝐻2superscriptsubscript𝑗1𝑁superscriptsubscript𝜎𝑗2\sigma_{H}^{2}:=\sum_{j=1}^{N}\sigma_{j}^{2} such that, 𝔼​[‖𝐡^j→k−𝐡j‖2]≤σj2𝔼delimited-[]superscriptnormsubscript^𝐡→𝑗𝑘subscript𝐡𝑗2superscriptsubscript𝜎𝑗2\mathbb{E}[\norm{\hat{{\boldsymbol{h}}}_{j\rightarrow k}-{\boldsymbol{h}}_{j}}^{2}]\leq\sigma_{j}^{2}.

Assumption 3.

(Graph Smoothing on Gradients) Graph 𝒢=(𝒱,ℰ)𝒢𝒱ℰ{\cal G}=({\cal V},{\cal E}) is connected graph and ∃κ2>0superscript𝜅20\exists\kappa^{2}>0 such that ∀𝐖for-all𝐖\forall{\boldsymbol{W}}, ∑(i,j)∈ℰ‖∇Fi​(𝐖)−∇Fj​(𝐖)‖2≤κ2subscript𝑖𝑗ℰsuperscriptnorm∇subscript𝐹𝑖𝐖∇subscript𝐹𝑗𝐖2superscript𝜅2\sum_{(i,j)\in{\cal E}}\norm{\nabla F_{i}({\boldsymbol{W}})-\nabla F_{j}({\boldsymbol{W}})}^{2}\leq\kappa^{2}.

Assumption 4.

(Bounds for Stochastic Gradient)
(i) (Bounded Variance) Variance of unbiased stochastic gradient ∇fk​(𝐖;𝚵𝒢)∇subscript𝑓𝑘𝐖subscript𝚵𝒢\nabla f_{k}({\boldsymbol{W}};{\boldsymbol{\Xi}}_{{\cal G}}) is bounded. Formally, ∃σ𝒢2>0superscriptsubscript𝜎𝒢20\exists\sigma_{{\cal G}}^{2}>0 such that ∀𝐖for-all𝐖\forall{\boldsymbol{W}},

∑k=1N𝔼​[‖∇fk​(𝑾;𝚵𝒢)−∇Fk​(𝑾)‖2]≤σ𝒢2.superscriptsubscript𝑘1𝑁𝔼delimited-[]superscriptnorm∇subscript𝑓𝑘𝑾subscript𝚵𝒢∇subscript𝐹𝑘𝑾2superscriptsubscript𝜎𝒢2\displaystyle\sum_{k=1}^{N}\mathbb{E}[\norm{\nabla f_{k}({\boldsymbol{W}};{\boldsymbol{\Xi}}_{{\cal G}})-\nabla F_{k}({\boldsymbol{W}})}^{2}]\leq\sigma_{{\cal G}}^{2}. (6)

(ii) (Smoothness) Denote ∇fk​(𝐖;𝚵𝒢)=ϕk​(𝐡1,…,𝐡N)∇subscript𝑓𝑘𝐖subscript𝚵𝒢subscriptitalic-ϕ𝑘subscript𝐡1…subscript𝐡𝑁\nabla f_{k}({\boldsymbol{W}};{\boldsymbol{\Xi}}_{{\cal G}})=\phi_{k}({\boldsymbol{h}}_{1},...,{\boldsymbol{h}}_{N}). Assume for any k∈[N]𝑘delimited-[]𝑁k\in[N], ϕksubscriptitalic-ϕ𝑘\phi_{k} satisfies that ∀𝐡i,𝐡i′for-allsubscript𝐡𝑖superscriptsubscript𝐡𝑖′\forall{\boldsymbol{h}}_{i},{\boldsymbol{h}}_{i}^{\prime} and i∈[N]𝑖delimited-[]𝑁i\in[N], ∃ρϕ>0subscript𝜌italic-ϕ0\exists\rho_{\phi}>0 such that,

‖ϕk​(𝒉1,…,𝒉N)−ϕk​(𝒉1′,…,𝒉N′)‖≤ρϕ​(∑i=1N‖𝒉i−𝒉i′‖)1/2.normsubscriptitalic-ϕ𝑘subscript𝒉1…subscript𝒉𝑁subscriptitalic-ϕ𝑘superscriptsubscript𝒉1′…superscriptsubscript𝒉𝑁′subscript𝜌italic-ϕsuperscriptsuperscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑁normsubscript𝒉𝑖superscriptsubscript𝒉𝑖′12\displaystyle\norm{\phi_{k}({\boldsymbol{h}}_{1},...,{\boldsymbol{h}}_{N})-\phi_{k}({\boldsymbol{h}}_{1}^{\prime},...,{\boldsymbol{h}}_{N}^{\prime})}\leq\rho_{\phi}\big{(}\sum_{i=1}^{N}\norm{{\boldsymbol{h}}_{i}-{\boldsymbol{h}}_{i}^{\prime}}\big{)}^{1/2}. (7)

Interpretation of Assumptions. (i) Assumption 1 is commonly assumed in the literature on nonconvex optimization and FL. (ii) Assumption 2 is the goodness of hidden representations estimation. σj2superscriptsubscript𝜎𝑗2\sigma_{j}^{2} represents the estimation error of 𝒉^j→ksubscript^𝒉→𝑗𝑘\hat{{\boldsymbol{h}}}_{j\rightarrow k} and σH2superscriptsubscript𝜎𝐻2\sigma_{H}^{2} quantifies the total estimation error. (iii) κ2superscript𝜅2\kappa^{2} in Assumption 3 quantifies this statistical heterogeneity among clients by considering the network structure which captures the relationship among clients’ distributions. A previous work [22] shows that there is a connection between data distribution shift among clients and the gradient shift among clients. Lemma A.4 provides the upper bound for the level of statistical heterogeneity based on κ2superscript𝜅2\kappa^{2} and connectivity of 𝒢𝒢{\cal G}. (iv) Assumption 4 ensures ∇fk​(𝑾;𝚵𝒢)∇subscript𝑓𝑘𝑾subscript𝚵𝒢\nabla f_{k}({\boldsymbol{W}};{\boldsymbol{\Xi}}_{{\cal G}}) satisfies two properties. First, it has a bounded variance (σ𝒢2superscriptsubscript𝜎𝒢2\sigma_{{\cal G}}^{2}) which is commonly presumed in previous works. The second one is a sense of smoothness of ∇fk​(𝑾;𝚵𝒢)∇subscript𝑓𝑘𝑾subscript𝚵𝒢\nabla f_{k}({\boldsymbol{W}};{\boldsymbol{\Xi}}_{{\cal G}}) in terms of a function of hidden representations with smoothness quantified by ρϕsubscript𝜌italic-ϕ\rho_{\phi}.

Remark 2.

According to our Theorem 4.1 and Corollary 4.2, when σH2=0superscriptsubscript𝜎𝐻20\sigma_{H}^{2}=0, that is, ignoring the node-level privacy issue and access to the unbiased stochastic gradient, our convergence result matches the rate of the previous works [33, 34, 35] with the gradient deviation among clients is described by a graph structure. For the effect from graph structure, since λmax​(𝐁N​𝐋†)subscript𝜆subscript𝐁𝑁superscript𝐋†\lambda_{\max}({\boldsymbol{B}}_{N}{\boldsymbol{L}}^{\dagger}) is an indication of the connectivity of graph 𝒢𝒢{\cal G} with normalized by averaged aggregation 𝐁Nsubscript𝐁𝑁{\boldsymbol{B}}_{N} (large λmax​(𝐁N​𝐋†)subscript𝜆subscript𝐁𝑁superscript𝐋†\lambda_{\max}({\boldsymbol{B}}_{N}{\boldsymbol{L}}^{\dagger}) means a bad connectivity and high level of statistical heterogeneity), we can expect that a graph with good connectivity ensures a better performances as shown in Figure 2. This observation matches our intuition that a smaller level of statistical heterogeneity in FL secures a better performance. Moreover, our Corollary 4.2 keep the linear speed up (w.r.t number of clients) when I=1𝐼1I=1 [36].

5 GFL-APPNP for Classification

5.1 GFL for Classification Tasks on Graphs

Deterministic Node Classification (DNC). Graph-based semi-supervised node classification is the most popular classification task on graphs. In this paper, we call it deterministic node classification since 𝝃ksubscript𝝃𝑘{\boldsymbol{\xi}}_{k} for each node is deterministic with one feature vector and one label. The GFL problem can formulate this task in §§\S 3 by assuming 𝝃ksubscript𝝃𝑘{\boldsymbol{\xi}}_{k} is from a degenerated distribution.

Stochastic Node Classification (SNC). An extended version of the deterministic node classification is the setting where local distribution at each node is not degenerated, namely stochastic node classification. This task is a semi-supervised node classification that classifies the nodes by learning from local distributions. Similarly, this task can be formulated by the GFL problem in §§\S 3 by assuming the randomness of 𝚵𝒢subscript𝚵𝒢{\boldsymbol{\Xi}}_{{\cal G}} is only from 𝑿𝑿{\boldsymbol{X}}. An important real-world application for this task is the user demographic label prediction in social networks.

Supervised Classification (SC). Consider the supervised learning task on clients, which is another classification task on graphs assuming the label of a client also follows a distribution. We call it supervised classification. The objective of this task is to classify the feature vectors in all clients. This task assumes the randomness of 𝚵𝒢subscript𝚵𝒢{\boldsymbol{\Xi}}_{{\cal G}} is from both 𝑿𝑿{\boldsymbol{X}} and 𝒀𝒀{\boldsymbol{Y}}, resulting in that each client might have examples with different labels. One practical application is the patient classification problem in hospitals with insufficient medical records.

More details about classification tasks are provided in Appendix D.1. Moreover, our GFL setting introduced in §§\S 3 is not only for standard supervised learning but also can be easily extended to semi-supervised client classification like DNC and SNC.

5.2 GFL-APPNP Algorithm

Approximate Personalized Propagation of Neural Predictions (APPNP) [37] is one of the state-of-the-art GNN models. With the notations and context in Section 3, APPNP has the hidden encoder ΨhsubscriptΨℎ\Psi_{h} and neighborhood aggregator Ψ𝒢subscriptΨ𝒢\Psi_{{\cal G}} defined as follow,

𝒉ksubscript𝒉𝑘\displaystyle{\boldsymbol{h}}_{k} =Ψh​(𝒙k;𝑾)=MLP​(𝒙k;𝑾),absentsubscriptΨℎsubscript𝒙𝑘𝑾MLPsubscript𝒙𝑘𝑾\displaystyle=\Psi_{h}({\boldsymbol{x}}_{k};{\boldsymbol{W}})={\mbox{MLP}}({\boldsymbol{x}}_{k};{\boldsymbol{W}}), (10a)
𝒁𝒁\displaystyle{\boldsymbol{Z}} =∑i=0M(1−α​I​{i≠M})​αi​(𝑫^−1/2​𝑨^​𝑫^−1/2)i​𝑯=𝑨~​𝑯,absentsuperscriptsubscript𝑖0𝑀1𝛼𝐼𝑖𝑀superscript𝛼𝑖superscriptsuperscript^𝑫12bold-^𝑨superscript^𝑫12𝑖𝑯bold-~𝑨𝑯\displaystyle=\sum_{i=0}^{M}(1-\alpha I\{i\neq M\})\alpha^{i}(\hat{{\boldsymbol{D}}}^{-1/2}{\boldsymbol{\hat{A}}}\hat{{\boldsymbol{D}}}^{-1/2})^{i}{\boldsymbol{H}}={\boldsymbol{\tilde{A}}}{\boldsymbol{H}}, (10b)

where α𝛼\alpha is teleport probability [37] and M𝑀M is the total steps for personalized propagation. 𝑨^bold-^𝑨{\boldsymbol{\hat{A}}} is the adjacency matrix with self-loop, and 𝑫^^𝑫\hat{{\boldsymbol{D}}} is the degree matrix with self-loop. 𝑨~bold-~𝑨{\boldsymbol{\tilde{A}}} is defined as 𝑨~:=∑i=0M(1−α​I​{i≠M})​αi​(𝑫^−1/2​𝑨^​𝑫^−1/2)iassignbold-~𝑨superscriptsubscript𝑖0𝑀1𝛼𝐼𝑖𝑀superscript𝛼𝑖superscriptsuperscript^𝑫12bold-^𝑨superscript^𝑫12𝑖{\boldsymbol{\tilde{A}}}:=\sum_{i=0}^{M}(1-\alpha I\{i\neq M\})\alpha^{i}(\hat{{\boldsymbol{D}}}^{-1/2}{\boldsymbol{\hat{A}}}\hat{{\boldsymbol{D}}}^{-1/2})^{i}. It can be interpreted as the "adjacency matrix" after M𝑀M steps random walk, which shows the reachability between two nodes in the structure after propagations. Loss function ℓℓ\ell in APPNP is the cross entropy loss. In APPNP, 𝑾hsubscript𝑾ℎ{\boldsymbol{W}}_{h} discussed in Eq.(3) refers to 𝑾𝑾{\boldsymbol{W}} since the neighborhood aggregator in APPNP is not parametrized. Note that original APPNP is proposed to solve the deterministic node classification task. Denote predicted one-hot vectors as 𝒀^=Softmax​(𝒁)^𝒀Softmax𝒁\hat{{\boldsymbol{Y}}}={\mbox{Softmax}}({\boldsymbol{Z}}) where Softmax​(⋅)Softmax⋅{\mbox{Softmax}}(\cdot) is a row-wise softmax function. The gradients can be expressed explicitly as follow,

∇fk​(𝑾;𝚵𝒢)=(𝒚k−𝒚^k)​∑i=1N𝑨~k​i​∇𝒉i,∇subscript𝑓𝑘𝑾subscript𝚵𝒢subscript𝒚𝑘subscript^𝒚𝑘superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑁subscriptbold-~𝑨𝑘𝑖∇subscript𝒉𝑖\displaystyle\nabla f_{k}({\boldsymbol{W}};{\boldsymbol{\Xi}}_{{\cal G}})=({\boldsymbol{y}}_{k}-\hat{{\boldsymbol{y}}}_{k})\sum_{i=1}^{N}{\boldsymbol{\tilde{A}}}_{ki}\nabla{\boldsymbol{h}}_{i}, (11)

where 𝒚ksubscript𝒚𝑘{\boldsymbol{y}}_{k} is the one-hot vector for the true label of client k𝑘k and 𝒚^ksubscript^𝒚𝑘\hat{{\boldsymbol{y}}}_{k} is the predicted probability vector for the label of client k𝑘k. 𝑨~k​isubscriptbold-~𝑨𝑘𝑖{\boldsymbol{\tilde{A}}}_{ki} is the element in matrix 𝑨~bold-~𝑨{\boldsymbol{\tilde{A}}}. Note that the hidden representation sharing contributes to two parts in the gradient for local loss fksubscript𝑓𝑘f_{k}: one is 𝒚^ksubscript^𝒚𝑘\hat{{\boldsymbol{y}}}_{k} and the other one is {∇𝒉i}i≠ksubscript∇subscript𝒉𝑖𝑖𝑘\{\nabla{\boldsymbol{h}}_{i}\}_{i\neq k}. A good property of using personalized propagation as the neighborhood aggregator is the linearity, which means

𝒚^ksubscript^𝒚𝑘\displaystyle\hat{{\boldsymbol{y}}}_{k} =Softmax​(𝑨~k​k​𝒉k+𝑪k),absentSoftmaxsubscriptbold-~𝑨𝑘𝑘subscript𝒉𝑘subscript𝑪𝑘\displaystyle={\mbox{Softmax}}({\boldsymbol{\tilde{A}}}_{kk}{\boldsymbol{h}}_{k}+{\boldsymbol{C}}_{k}), (12a)
∇fk​(𝑾;𝚵𝒢)∇subscript𝑓𝑘𝑾subscript𝚵𝒢\displaystyle\nabla f_{k}({\boldsymbol{W}};{\boldsymbol{\Xi}}_{{\cal G}}) =(𝒚k−𝒚^k)​(𝑨~k​k​∇𝒉k+∇𝑪k),absentsubscript𝒚𝑘subscript^𝒚𝑘subscriptbold-~𝑨𝑘𝑘∇subscript𝒉𝑘∇subscript𝑪𝑘\displaystyle=({\boldsymbol{y}}_{k}-\hat{{\boldsymbol{y}}}_{k})({\boldsymbol{\tilde{A}}}_{kk}\nabla{\boldsymbol{h}}_{k}+\nabla{\boldsymbol{C}}_{k}), (12b)

where 𝑪k:=∑i≠k𝑨~k​i​𝒉iassignsubscript𝑪𝑘subscript𝑖𝑘subscriptbold-~𝑨𝑘𝑖subscript𝒉𝑖{\boldsymbol{C}}_{k}:=\sum_{i\neq k}{\boldsymbol{\tilde{A}}}_{ki}{\boldsymbol{h}}_{i} and ∇𝑪k:=∑i≠k𝑨~k​i​∇𝒉iassign∇subscript𝑪𝑘subscript𝑖𝑘subscriptbold-~𝑨𝑘𝑖∇subscript𝒉𝑖\nabla{\boldsymbol{C}}_{k}:=\sum_{i\neq k}{\boldsymbol{\tilde{A}}}_{ki}\nabla{\boldsymbol{h}}_{i}. Clearly, 𝑪ksubscript𝑪𝑘{\boldsymbol{C}}_{k} and its gradient ∇𝑪k∇subscript𝑪𝑘\nabla{\boldsymbol{C}}_{k} are aggregated information for client k𝑘k. Therefore, in practice, the central server only needs to broadcast 𝑪ksubscript𝑪𝑘{\boldsymbol{C}}_{k} and its gradient to client k𝑘k in the communication round, which provides private communication since the hidden representations are not shared directly.

We propose GFL-APPNP algorithm for GFL problem on classification tasks, using hidden representation sharing. In addition, we use the latest aggregated model to compute hidden representations at each communication round as our gradient compensation strategy. As a concrete example, consider client j𝑗j has njsubscript𝑛𝑗n_{j} local feature vectors {𝒙j,s}s=1njsuperscriptsubscriptsubscript𝒙𝑗𝑠𝑠1subscript𝑛𝑗\{{\boldsymbol{x}}_{j,s}\}_{s=1}^{n_{j}}, suppose t0<tsubscript𝑡0𝑡t_{0}<t is the largest multiple of I𝐼I,

𝒉^j→kt={Ψh​(𝒙k;𝑾h,kt)j=k1nj​∑s=1njΨh​(𝒙j,s;𝑾¯ht0)j≠k,subscriptsuperscript^𝒉𝑡→𝑗𝑘casessubscriptΨℎsubscript𝒙𝑘subscriptsuperscript𝑾𝑡ℎ𝑘𝑗𝑘1subscript𝑛𝑗superscriptsubscript𝑠1subscript𝑛𝑗subscriptΨℎsubscript𝒙𝑗𝑠subscriptsuperscript¯𝑾subscript𝑡0ℎ𝑗𝑘\displaystyle\hat{{\boldsymbol{h}}}^{t}_{j\rightarrow k}=\begin{cases}\Psi_{h}({\boldsymbol{x}}_{k};{\boldsymbol{W}}^{t}_{h,k})&j=k\\ \frac{1}{n_{j}}\sum_{s=1}^{n_{j}}\Psi_{h}({\boldsymbol{x}}_{j,s};\bar{{\boldsymbol{W}}}^{t_{0}}_{h})&j\neq k\end{cases}, (13)

where 𝒉^j→ktsubscriptsuperscript^𝒉𝑡→𝑗𝑘\hat{{\boldsymbol{h}}}^{t}_{j\rightarrow k} is the estimation for 𝒉j→ksubscript𝒉→𝑗𝑘{\boldsymbol{h}}_{j\rightarrow k} at time t𝑡t. Our compensation strategy satisfies the guarantee discussed in Assumption 2 with additional assumptions. See Appendix C.1 for detailed discussion for gradient compensation. Summary of GFL-APPNP is described in Algorithm 1. Our proposed GFL-APPNP is a FL version for APPNP, which fulfills the FL for a GNN model. It is noteworthy that GFL-APPNP with I=1𝐼1I=1 is equivalent to the FL for the vanilla APPNP for deterministic node classification tasks.

6 Experiments

6.1 Deterministic Node Classification

We compare the proposed GFL-APPNP to baseline models including GCN, GAT, and GraphSAGE under the DNC setting described in §§\S5.1. For synthetic data, we use contextual Stochastic Block Models (cSBMs) [38] to generate synthetic graphs with approximately two equal-size classes. For real-world data, we use subgraphs of Cora [39], namely subCora, due to the limitation of computational resources. The details of the generation of synthetic graphs by cSBMs and the generation of subCora graphs are provided in Appendix D.2. For the proposed GFL-APPNP, we use a two-layer MLP with 646464 hidden units. α𝛼\alpha is chosen to be 0.10.10.1 and the total number of steps for personalized propagation M𝑀M is set as 101010, following the same configuration as it in the [40] for the APPNP model. I𝐼I is set to be {1,10,20,50}1102050\{1,10,20,50\}. SGD is applied as our optimizer with the optimized learning rate. Baseline models including GCN, GAT, and GraphSAGE follow the same design of the well-optimized hyperparameters from [41, 42, 43]. The details for all models are provided in Appendix D.3. Table 1 and the first two columns of Figure 3 show that our method of different I𝐼I can match the performance of the vanilla APPNP on both synthetic graphs and subCora graphs. Our method rivals baseline models based on Table 1.

6.2 Stochastic Node Classification

We also conduct experiments under the SNC setting described in §§\S5.1 to test the robustness of GFL-APPNP. As we know, current graph machine learning models are not designed for the SNC task. Therefore our experiment will focus on the proposed GFL-APPNP. The original cSBMs can not be used to generate data for this task since they are not designed to generate graphs whose nodes have multiple features. We modify the original cSBMs to generate distributions for each client. Details about the modifications for the SNC task are available in Appendix D.2. Similar to §§\S6.1, we use the same hyperparameters and the same number of updates. The third column of Figure 3 and additional Table 2 provided in Appendix D.4 show that our method is valid for solving the SNC task.

6.3 Supervised Classification

We compare GFL-APPNP, MLPs, and FedMLP under the SC setting described in §§\S5.1. Similar to the SNC task, we modify the original cSBMs to generate distributions for each client. Details about the modifications for the SC task are given in Appendix D.2 as well. Both baseline models MLPs and FedMLP share the same model structure, a two-layer MLP model with 646464 hidden units. Similar to §§\S6.1, for the proposed GFL-APPNP, we use the same hyperparameters and the same numbers of updates. More details and results are provided in Appendix D. The last column of Figure 3 and Table 4 provided in Appendix D.4 shows that our method is valid for solving the SC task and it demonstrates the necessity of graph in GFL problem as shown in Figure 2.

7 Conclusion

In this paper, we formulate Graph Federated Learning on multi-client systems. To tackle the fundamental data sharing conflict between LoG and FL, we propose an FL solution with hidden representation sharing. In theory, we provide a non-convex convergence analysis. Empirically, by experimenting with several classification tasks on graphs, we validate the proposed method on both real-world and synthetic data. Our experimental results show that the proposed method provides an FL solution for GNNs and works for different practical tasks on graphs with a competitive performance that matches our theory.

Remark 3.

Lemma A.2 provides an upper bound for "mixed variation" which quantifies the variation from gradient at client k𝑘k with its local model and the averaged gradient of all clients with their own models. This variation is bounded by the sum of two types of variations: (i) Shift among the local models. (ii) Shift between the gradients among clients at the same model. Lemma A.3 gives the goodness for gradient estimation. This upper bound shows that the estimation error is basically from two types: (i) Variance of the unbiased estimator (σ𝒢2superscriptsubscript𝜎𝒢2\sigma_{{\cal G}}^{2}). (ii) Mean squared error of the hidden representation estimation (σH2superscriptsubscript𝜎𝐻2\sigma_{H}^{2}). Lemma A.4 is about the gradient deviation among working clients on graph 𝒢𝒢{\cal G}. This upper bound quantifies the level of statistical heterogeneity among clients in FL. Combining previous Lemmas, the expected total shift among the local models at all times is controlled in Lemma A.5.

𝒪​(1η​T)+𝒪​(1N​σ𝒢2)+𝒪​(σH2)+𝒪​(I2​η2​κ2​λmax​(𝑩N​𝑳†)N).𝒪1𝜂𝑇𝒪1𝑁superscriptsubscript𝜎𝒢2𝒪superscriptsubscript𝜎𝐻2𝒪superscript𝐼2superscript𝜂2superscript𝜅2subscript𝜆subscript𝑩𝑁superscript𝑳†𝑁\displaystyle{\cal O}(\frac{1}{\eta T})+{\cal O}(\frac{1}{N}\sigma_{{\cal G}}^{2})+{\cal O}(\sigma_{H}^{2})+{\cal O}(\frac{I^{2}\eta^{2}\kappa^{2}\lambda_{\max}({\boldsymbol{B}}_{N}{\boldsymbol{L}}^{\dagger})}{N}). (26)

However, I𝐼I and η𝜂\eta are parameters which can be tuned/chosen while ρfsubscript𝜌𝑓\rho_{f} is a smoothness constant. As a consequence, I𝐼I and η𝜂\eta are our interest and we keep the vanilla form by considering I2​η2superscript𝐼2superscript𝜂2I^{2}\eta^{2} is large enough, making (26) is the special case in our result. ∎

To solve this maximization problem, list the following useful facts:
(i) The Laplacian matrix 𝑳𝑳{\boldsymbol{L}} has eigenpair (0,𝟏)01(0,{\boldsymbol{1}}) and only one zero eigenvalue.
(ii) 𝟏⊤​𝑩N​𝟏=0superscript1topsubscript𝑩𝑁10{\boldsymbol{1}}^{\top}{\boldsymbol{B}}_{N}{\boldsymbol{1}}=0.

Now focus on the following optimization problem,

{2​𝑩N​𝒙−2​μ​𝑳​𝒙=0𝒙⊤​𝑳​𝒙≤δ2μ​(𝒙⊤​𝑳​𝒙−δ2)=0cases2subscript𝑩𝑁𝒙2𝜇𝑳𝒙0otherwisesuperscript𝒙top𝑳𝒙superscript𝛿2otherwise𝜇superscript𝒙top𝑳𝒙superscript𝛿20otherwise\displaystyle\begin{cases}2{\boldsymbol{B}}_{N}{\boldsymbol{x}}-2\mu{\boldsymbol{L}}{\boldsymbol{x}}=0\\ {\boldsymbol{x}}^{\top}{\boldsymbol{L}}{\boldsymbol{x}}\leq\delta^{2}\\ \mu({\boldsymbol{x}}^{\top}{\boldsymbol{L}}{\boldsymbol{x}}-\delta^{2})=0\end{cases} (34)

Focus on the case that μ>0𝜇0\mu>0 since μ=0𝜇0\mu=0 indicates 𝒙=𝟎𝒙0{\boldsymbol{x}}={\boldsymbol{0}} and the objective is 00 which is trivial. Note that 𝒗1=𝟏subscript𝒗11{\boldsymbol{v}}_{1}={\boldsymbol{1}}. Then,

𝑳𝑳\displaystyle{\boldsymbol{L}} =∑i=2Nλi​𝒗i​𝒗i⊤absentsuperscriptsubscript𝑖2𝑁subscript𝜆𝑖subscript𝒗𝑖superscriptsubscript𝒗𝑖top\displaystyle=\sum_{i=2}^{N}\lambda_{i}{\boldsymbol{v}}_{i}{\boldsymbol{v}}_{i}^{\top} (35a)
𝑳1/2superscript𝑳12\displaystyle{\boldsymbol{L}}^{1/2} =∑i=2Nλi​𝒗i​𝒗i⊤absentsuperscriptsubscript𝑖2𝑁subscript𝜆𝑖subscript𝒗𝑖superscriptsubscript𝒗𝑖top\displaystyle=\sum_{i=2}^{N}\sqrt{\lambda_{i}}{\boldsymbol{v}}_{i}{\boldsymbol{v}}_{i}^{\top} (35b)

Appendix C Additional Works

C.1 Analysis for Gradient Compensation

To solve classification tasks formulated as a GFL problem with hidden representation sharing, as discussed in Section 3.4, we suggest a straightforward gradient estimation strategy, namely gradient compensation. To present the proposed gradient estimation scheme, further define

𝒉j→ktsubscriptsuperscript𝒉𝑡→𝑗𝑘\displaystyle{\boldsymbol{h}}^{t}_{j\rightarrow k} =Ψh​(𝒙j;𝑾h,kt)absentsubscriptΨℎsubscript𝒙𝑗subscriptsuperscript𝑾𝑡ℎ𝑘\displaystyle=\Psi_{h}({\boldsymbol{x}}_{j};{\boldsymbol{W}}^{t}_{h,k}) (50a)

where 𝑾h,ktsubscriptsuperscript𝑾𝑡ℎ𝑘{\boldsymbol{W}}^{t}_{h,k} is part of 𝑾ktsubscriptsuperscript𝑾𝑡𝑘{\boldsymbol{W}}^{t}_{k} for client k𝑘k at round t𝑡t and 𝒉j→ktsubscriptsuperscript𝒉𝑡→𝑗𝑘{\boldsymbol{h}}^{t}_{j\rightarrow k} is the hidden representation of client j𝑗j for the local updates at client k𝑘k at round t𝑡t. Our compensation strategy satisfies the guarantee discussed in Assumption 2 with additional assumptions. Specifically, suppose Eq.(13) is used, that is, latest aggregated model is broadcast to estimate the hidden representation, the squared estimation error of 𝒉^tj→ksuperscriptsubscript^𝒉𝑡→𝑗𝑘\hat{{\boldsymbol{h}}}_{t}^{j\rightarrow k} is bounded under following assumptions.

Following Lemma C.1 formally shows that our gradient compensation is valid for the nonconvex result in Section 4,

Lemma C.1.

Consider the federated learning procedure described in Section 3 under Assumptions 5 and 6. Gradient compensation (13) provides estimation with bounded mean squared error. Formally, for any round t𝑡t, ∀j∈[N]for-all𝑗delimited-[]𝑁\forall j\in[N] and ∀k∈[N]for-all𝑘delimited-[]𝑁\forall k\in[N],

Proof.

See Appendix C.2. ∎

Lemma C.1 shows that our compensation strategy (13) satisfies that σk2=2​η2​ρh2​I2​Δksuperscriptsubscript𝜎𝑘22superscript𝜂2superscriptsubscript𝜌ℎ2superscript𝐼2subscriptΔ𝑘\sigma_{k}^{2}=2\eta^{2}\rho_{h}^{2}I^{2}\Delta_{k} and σH2=2​η2​ρh2​I2​Δsuperscriptsubscript𝜎𝐻22superscript𝜂2superscriptsubscript𝜌ℎ2superscript𝐼2Δ\sigma_{H}^{2}=2\eta^{2}\rho_{h}^{2}I^{2}\Delta in Assumption 2. This theoretical guarantee ensures that proposed gradient compensation strategy matches nonconvex results provided in Section 4.

C.2 Proof of Lemma C.1

Proof.

𝒉j→ktsubscriptsuperscript𝒉𝑡→𝑗𝑘\displaystyle{\boldsymbol{h}}^{t}_{j\rightarrow k} =Ψh​(𝒙j;𝑾h,tk)absentsubscriptΨℎsubscript𝒙𝑗superscriptsubscript𝑾ℎ𝑡𝑘\displaystyle=\Psi_{h}({\boldsymbol{x}}_{j};{\boldsymbol{W}}_{h,t}^{k}) (56a)
𝒉^j→ktsubscriptsuperscript^𝒉𝑡→𝑗𝑘\displaystyle\hat{{\boldsymbol{h}}}^{t}_{j\rightarrow k} =1nj​∑s=1njΨh​(𝒙j,s;𝑾¯ht0)absent1subscript𝑛𝑗superscriptsubscript𝑠1subscript𝑛𝑗subscriptΨℎsubscript𝒙𝑗𝑠subscriptsuperscript¯𝑾subscript𝑡0ℎ\displaystyle=\frac{1}{n_{j}}\sum_{s=1}^{n_{j}}\Psi_{h}({\boldsymbol{x}}_{j,s};\bar{{\boldsymbol{W}}}^{t_{0}}_{h}) (56b)

Note that 𝒙jsubscript𝒙𝑗{\boldsymbol{x}}_{j} and {𝒙j,s}s=1njsuperscriptsubscriptsubscript𝒙𝑗𝑠𝑠1subscript𝑛𝑗\{{\boldsymbol{x}}_{j,s}\}_{s=1}^{n_{j}} are i.i.d. Suppose t0<tsubscript𝑡0𝑡t_{0}<t is the largest multiple of I𝐼I, we have,

C.3 Mechanism of Proposed Method

Role of Hidden Encoder. The hidden encoder is a global model shared across the clients, which is why FL is valid (collaboration is valid). It is a model ignoring the graph information. Intuitively, ΨhsubscriptΨℎ\Psi_{h} not only serves as a "privacy protection encoder" but also a "representation extracting model" for the target machine learning task. With the "privacy protection encoder", raw data of any local client is not shared with both the central server and other clients. In this sense, it serves as a privacy-preserving encoder. In addition, since clients have the same task, we assume Ψh:𝒙→𝒉:subscriptΨℎ→𝒙𝒉\Psi_{h}:{\boldsymbol{x}}\rightarrow{\boldsymbol{h}} is shared to extract representations for the target task. Note that if we set Ψ𝒢subscriptΨ𝒢\Psi_{{\cal G}} as the identity mapping (ignore the graph information), our solution reduces to the conventional FL solution to learn a global model ΨhsubscriptΨℎ\Psi_{h}.

Role of Neighborhood Aggregator. The neighborhood aggregator in our solution is the personalized model, which uses graph information to account for statistical heterogeneity. We use the term "personalization" because graph representation for each client is personalized by the graph-based model Ψ𝒢subscriptΨ𝒢\Psi_{{\cal G}}. For example, the most simple neighborhood aggregator is the simple graph convolution: Ψ𝒢​(𝑯)=𝑨​𝑯subscriptΨ𝒢𝑯𝑨𝑯\Psi_{{\cal G}}({\boldsymbol{H}})={\boldsymbol{A}}{\boldsymbol{H}} (without learnable parameters), which uses 𝑨𝑨{\boldsymbol{A}} as the smoothing matrix. By involving the neighborhood aggregator, our method can be viewed as a personalized FL. Personalization (or graph) is necessary due to the existence of statistical heterogeneity in multi-client systems (see Figure 2). In short, Ψ𝒢subscriptΨ𝒢\Psi_{{\cal G}} serves as modeling the heterogeneity using graph 𝒢𝒢{\cal G}. Note that when 𝒢𝒢{\cal G} does not fully capture the Non-IID relationship across clients, 𝑾𝒢subscript𝑾𝒢{\boldsymbol{W}}_{{\cal G}} serves as weights for adjusting the neighborhood aggregation level using 𝒢𝒢{\cal G} to approximate the true structure of heterogeneity.

C.4 Privacy Protection in GFL

FL requires the protection of node-level privacy: client can not share their own collected data with both other clients and the central server directly. This node-level privacy is supposed to be protected in GFL. According to [44], sharing both model parameters, hidden representations, and gradients to the clients is subject to the raw data leakage problem, which violates the node-level privacy. In other words, directly sharing {𝒉j,∇𝒉j}j=1Nsuperscriptsubscriptsubscript𝒉𝑗∇subscript𝒉𝑗𝑗1𝑁\{{\boldsymbol{h}}_{j},\nabla{\boldsymbol{h}}_{j}\}_{j=1}^{N} raises the concern about raw data recovery by untrustworthy clients or the central server. Fortunately, our proposed solution in §§\S 3, which allows sharing of hidden representations and the corresponding gradients during the communication between clients and the central server, does not violate node-level privacy. We provide a detailed explanation by considering the following two cases: (I) Raw data recovered by clients. (II) Raw data recovered by the central server.

(I) Our hidden representation sharing technique can strictly avoid the first case due to the utility of personalized neighbor aggregator Ψ𝒢subscriptΨ𝒢\Psi_{\mathcal{G}}. Thanks to graph 𝒢𝒢{\cal G}, the central server allocates the uploaded hidden representations and their gradients and broadcasts the graph-based aggregated representations and gradients to the clients, indicating that each client will not directly receive the latest hidden representation and the corresponding gradient of its neighborhood. Instead, each client receives aggregated information about hidden representations and the gradients. For instance, in §§\S 5, in proposed GFL-APPNP with notations given in Algorithm 1, client k𝑘k can only receive the latest Cksubscript𝐶𝑘C_{k} and ∇Ck∇subscript𝐶𝑘\nabla C_{k} for each communication round. Note that even though a client can know who its neighbors are, it has no access to the propagation matrix A~~𝐴\tilde{A}, since the number of steps for propagation is only known by the central server. As a result, client k𝑘k has no chance to recover the raw data of its neighborhood.

(II) The second case is also not a concern if one assumes the central server is trustworthy. If the central server is perfectly protected (central server is not possible to be an attacker or be hacked), since raw data is not shared with the central server, node-level privacy is protected. In the extreme case that the central server is not reliable, we provide the following strategies to address this concern. First, improve the design of the central server. For example, use one server for receiving and allocating hidden representations and use the other server for gradients. Another way is releasing memories of hidden representations after broadcasting aggregated results and receiving the gradients after the release. Second, according to [44], one possible defense strategy is adding random noises to the gradients (noisy gradients), and we provide the corresponding experimental results using DP method in Appendix D.4.4.

Moreover, considering the classification tasks on graphs, described in Section 5.1, only the deterministic node classification is supposed to be discussed in the above cases. Stochastic node classification and supervised classification are impossible for clients and central server to receive {𝒉j,∇𝒉j}j=1Nsuperscriptsubscriptsubscript𝒉𝑗∇subscript𝒉𝑗𝑗1𝑁\{{\boldsymbol{h}}_{j},\nabla{\boldsymbol{h}}_{j}\}_{j=1}^{N} directly. The reason is that clients have multiple feature vectors and only upload the average hidden representations and gradients (See Eq.(13)).

Finally, GFL is protecting data privacy by succeeding the nature of FL. Therefore, unlike differential privacy (DP), our GFL is not designed for measuring the quantity of privacy level and corresponding performance loss based on privacy. Even though it is interesting to combine the DP method in GFL, we leave the comprehensive work on DP in GFL as a potentially promising future work. We only experiment noisy gradient for GFL in Appendix D.4.4, inspired by DP methods.

Appendix D Supplement to Experiments

D.1 Tasks Description

Deterministic Node Classification. The most common classification task on relational data is semi-supervised node classification which is transductive learning. In this work, we call the classical semi-supervised node classification the deterministic node classification since 𝝃ksubscript𝝃𝑘{\boldsymbol{\xi}}_{k} for each node is deterministic with one feature vector and one label. In this task, a graph-based model is going to classify the label of the test nodes given the feature vectors and the graph structure for all nodes and the label of training nodes. GFL problem is the federated learning version of this task by setting 𝝃k=(𝒙k,yk)subscript𝝃𝑘subscript𝒙𝑘subscript𝑦𝑘{\boldsymbol{\xi}}_{k}=({\boldsymbol{x}}_{k},y_{k}) is from a deterministic distribution which means 𝝃𝒢subscript𝝃𝒢{\boldsymbol{\xi}}_{{\cal G}} is not random. Note that in GFL, the unlabeled clients do not participate in local updates, but they have to compute and upload hidden representations. Also, the connectivity mentioned in Assumption 3 is on the graph of labeled clients. The local updates to solve the GFL problem in this task are biased gradient descent using the deterministic feature vector and the estimated hidden representations. Note that this is the special case of stochastic node classification when local data of node k𝑘k is assumed to be degenerated distributed.

Stochastic Node Classification. Suppose the graph structure describes the relationship between the distributions among the nodes, the extended version of the classical semi-supervised node classification task on a graph is classifying the label of the test nodes given the samples from all nodes and the graph structure as well as the fixed labels of training nodes. This task assumes the randomness of 𝝃ksubscript𝝃𝑘{\boldsymbol{\xi}}_{k} is only from 𝒙ksubscript𝒙𝑘{\boldsymbol{x}}_{k} but not 𝒚ksubscript𝒚𝑘{\boldsymbol{y}}_{k}. In other words, this task can be formulated by the GFL problem in Section 3 by assuming the randomness of 𝚵𝒢subscript𝚵𝒢{\boldsymbol{\Xi}}_{{\cal G}} is only from 𝑿𝑿{\boldsymbol{X}} but not 𝒀𝒀{\boldsymbol{Y}}. GFL is the federated learning version of this task. Similar to the deterministic one, in GFL, the unlabeled clients do not participate in local updates while they must share hidden representations, and the connectivity for convergence refers to the graph of labeled clients. The local updates to solve the GFL problem in this task is biased SGD with batches sampled from the given examples. This task is novel to the current graph machine learning community and harder than deterministic node classification. The applications of this task are discussed as follows with two practical examples: (i) User demographic label prediction in a social network. Given the network of users for some cell phone app and suppose users’ cell phones provide the computational resources and collect the behavior data, predicting the demographic label (such as gender, age group, etc.) of a new user with behavior data in the network is the stochastic node classification problem. (ii) Classifying hospitals. Based on the network of hospitals and the patients’ records, classifying a new hospital in the network is also a stochastic node classification.

Supervised Classification. This task assumes the randomness of 𝝃ksubscript𝝃𝑘{\boldsymbol{\xi}}_{k} is from both 𝒙ksubscript𝒙𝑘{\boldsymbol{x}}_{k} and 𝒚ksubscript𝒚𝑘{\boldsymbol{y}}_{k}, indicating that each node might have examples with different labels. In other words, This task assumes the randomness of 𝚵𝒢subscript𝚵𝒢{\boldsymbol{\Xi}}_{{\cal G}} is from both 𝑿𝑿{\boldsymbol{X}} and 𝒀𝒀{\boldsymbol{Y}}. The objective of this task is to classify the feature vector in some clients, given training data among all nodes with a graph structure. Similar to stochastic node classification, GFL is the federated learning version of this task, and local updates to solve the GFL problem in this task are biased SGD with batches sampled from the given examples. One application is also based on the users’ network from some cell phone app: suppose users’ cell phones provide the computational resources and collect the hourly activity data. Labeling the incoming data of the users in the network is a supervised classification task. Another application is classifying patients in a hospital located as a node in a hospital network: suppose some hospital has an insufficient record for some special type of patients, information from other hospitals in the network can help classify these patients in that hospital, and this refers to the supervised classification task with LoG.

Our GFL setting introduced in Section 3 is not only for standard supervised learning but also can be easily extended to semi-supervised client classification by following additional constructions. The labeled clients perform local updates while unlabeled ones only need to share hidden representations. The connectivity of graphs with labeled clients, which is a subgraph of 𝒢𝒢{\cal G}, will directly affect convergence performance as discussed in Section 4.

D.2 Data Generations in Section 6

This part provides a detailed description of the data generation (including synthetic data and real data) for our experiments in Section 6. There are three settings in our experiment: deterministic node classification using simulated data, deterministic node classification using real data, and stochastic node classification using simulated data. In our data generation procedure, cSBMs are utilized multiple times, and we will start with a brief recap of cSBMs and then the detailed data generation for three settings in our empirical study. For an illustrative purpose, we overload some notations in this Section (Appendix D.2), and these notations are only valid in this part. In other words, the notations used in this Section are not the same as in other parts of our paper.

Recap of cSBMs. Contextual Stochastic Block Models (cSBMs) is proposed by [38]. In this section, we briefly present how to generate a synthetic graph G𝐺G using cSBMs. Suppose there are N𝑁N nodes form two clusters of approximately equal size with node labels 𝒚∈{−1,1}N𝒚superscript11𝑁{\boldsymbol{y}}\in\{-1,1\}^{N}. Each node is assigned with a p𝑝p dimension Gaussian feature vector 𝒙i=μN​yi​𝒖+𝒁ipsubscript𝒙𝑖𝜇𝑁subscript𝑦𝑖𝒖subscript𝒁𝑖𝑝{\boldsymbol{x}}_{i}=\sqrt{\dfrac{\mu}{N}}y_{i}{\boldsymbol{u}}+\dfrac{{\boldsymbol{Z}}_{i}}{p}. Where 𝒖∼N​(0,𝑰p/p)similar-to𝒖𝑁0subscript𝑰𝑝𝑝{\boldsymbol{u}}\sim N(0,{\boldsymbol{I}}_{p}/p), 𝒁i∈ℝpsubscript𝒁𝑖superscriptℝ𝑝{\boldsymbol{Z}}_{i}\in\mathbb{R}^{p} has independent standard normal entries, and μ𝜇\mu is a hyperparameter that is fixed and known. The adjacency matrix 𝑨𝑨{\boldsymbol{A}} defines the undirected graph is determined by the following probabilistic model:

ℙ​(Ai,j=1)={d+λ​dN,if yi=yjd−λ​dN,otherwiseℙsubscript𝐴𝑖𝑗1cases𝑑𝜆𝑑𝑁if yi=yjotherwise𝑑𝜆𝑑𝑁otherwiseotherwise\displaystyle\mathbb{P}(A_{i,j}=1)=\begin{cases}\dfrac{d+\lambda\sqrt{d}}{N},\text{if $y_{i}=y_{j}$}\\ \dfrac{d-\lambda\sqrt{d}}{N},\text{otherwise}\end{cases} (58)

Where d𝑑d denotes the average degree, and λ𝜆\lambda denotes the normalized degree separation, which is also fixed and known for simplicity. In cSBMs, the difference between the means of two clusters is controlled by a parameter μ𝜇\mu, and the difference between the edge densities within each cluster and the edge densities between clusters is controlled by a parameter λ𝜆\lambda. Asymptotically, one needs λ2+μ2N/p>1superscript𝜆2superscript𝜇2𝑁𝑝1\lambda^{2}+\dfrac{\mu^{2}}{N/p}>1 to ensure a vanishing ratio of the misclassified nodes and the total number of nodes. As introduced in [40], we use ϕ=arctan⁡(λ​N/pμ×2π)italic-ϕarctangent𝜆𝑁𝑝𝜇2𝜋\phi=\arctan(\dfrac{\lambda\sqrt{N/p}}{\mu}\times\dfrac{2}{\pi}) to control the extent of information carried by the node features and graph topology. Note that ϕ=0italic-ϕ0\phi=0 indicates that only node features are informative while |ϕ|=1italic-ϕ1\absolutevalue{\phi}=1 indicates that only the graph topology is informative.

Synthetic Data for Deterministic Node Classification. In our experiment, 202020 synthetic graphs with one example per node are synthesized, and each of these 202020 graphs is generated by using cSBMs with d=8,λ=2,μ=1,N=200,p=100formulae-sequence𝑑8formulae-sequence𝜆2formulae-sequence𝜇1formulae-sequence𝑁200𝑝100d=8,\lambda=2,\mu=1,N=200,p=100, which are parameters described in the previous recap part. Then we fix the graph topology for all 20 generated synthetic graphs so they have the same structure with the same number of nodes, edges, and labels. We also fix the train-valid-test split (10%/10%/80%percent10percent10percent8010\%/10\%/80\%) for all 202020 graphs. The training set is balanced, which indicates that it has the same number of nodes for both two classes. Moreover, the subgraph induced by the nodes in the training set is connected. The ϕitalic-ϕ\phi value is approximately 0.780.780.78, and the dimension for the feature vector is 100100100. To achieve randomness in repeated simulations, we change the node features for each of these 202020 synthetic graphs.

Real Data for Deterministic Node Classification. Cora dataset is a citation graph that is widely used as a benchmark dataset for the semi-supervised node classification task. This dataset consists of 2708 nodes (scientific publications) classified into one of seven classes, and it consists of 542954295429 edges. The dimension of a node feature vector is 140314031403, which is a 0/1010/1-valued word vector indicating the absence/presence of the corresponding word from the dictionary, which consists of 143314331433 unique words. As our discussion in Section 6.1, due to our limited computational resources, instead of using the whole Cora for our experiments, we extract subgraphs with 300300300 nodes from Cora, namely subCora. The following steps describe the generation process of subCora. For each random seed from a large pool of random seeds:

  • 1)

    Randomly select 800800800 nodes from Cora using one random seed and find all connected components from this subgraph with 800800800 nodes.

  • 2)

    For each connected component, we keep it as one training set if it satisfies the following two conditions: (i) Size must fall between 303030 and 505050 including 303030 and 505050, which can ensure our training set only counts toward 10−15%10percent1510-15\% of the entire subCora graph with 300300300 nodes (ii) The connected component have all 777 classes, and the standard deviation of the counts for different classes is less than or equal to 2.52.52.5. Securing that our training set is as balanced as possible.

  • 3)

    To generate the corresponding validation set and the testing set, we find all reachable nodes from the training set using BFS with a maximum depth of 222, and select nodes from these reachable nodes as a validation set such that the validation size is equal to the training size. Then select testing nodes so that our subCora graph has 300300300 nodes in total. This step makes the extracted subCora graphs have good connectivity, which matches our Assumption 3.

By simulating subCora in this way, we make sure that the training sets are connected with all 777 classes and relatively good class balance. Also, the generated subCora graphs have relatively better connectivity than randomly selecting testing sets and validation sets.

Synthetic Data for Stochastic Node Classification.Unlike deterministic node classification, this task requires multiple examples for each node. The vanilla cSBMs are not designed for simulating data for this task. However, since statistical heterogeneity indicates the graph homophily on feature distribution, we can still utilize cSBMs to generate synthetic relational data with one label and multiple feature vectors for each node. Then the synthetic data can be generated by these distributions among clients. First, we use the original probabilistic model from cSBMs (D.2) to generate the graph structure (i.e., edges and nodes), and we assign a ±1plus-or-minus1\pm 1 label to each node by either manually assigning or using a Bernoulli distribution with success probability 0.50.50.5 to achieve a balance class set. To be more specific, the hyperparameters we used to generate the graph structure are d=10,μ=1,λ=2formulae-sequence𝑑10formulae-sequence𝜇1𝜆2d=10,\mu=1,\lambda=2 and N=200𝑁200N=200.

Select one training set that is connected and achieves class balance by simply selecting nodes randomly until the subgraph induced by these nodes is connected and it has class balance. Then randomly select the validation set, and testing set such that we have a 10%/10%/80%percent10percent10percent8010\%/10\%/80\% spilled.

Denote the label vector as 𝒗={v1,…,vN}∈{±1}N𝒗subscript𝑣1…subscript𝑣𝑁superscriptplus-or-minus1𝑁{\boldsymbol{v}}=\{v_{1},\dots,v_{N}\}\in\{\pm 1\}^{N}. And draw a 𝒖∼N​(0,𝑰p/p)similar-to𝒖𝑁0subscript𝑰𝑝𝑝{\boldsymbol{u}}\sim N(0,{\boldsymbol{I}}_{p}/p) where p=100𝑝100p=100, and it will be used later for feature vectors generation purpose. With these hyperparameters, the ϕitalic-ϕ\phi is set to be 0.780.780.78. Each node has 404040 local data points. The data sampling process for each node is described in the following,

Synthetic Data for Supervised Classification. We will use the Bernoulli distribution and multivariate Gaussian distribution to generate labels and feature vectors for each client/node. First, we use the original probabilistic model from cSBMs (D.2) to generate the graph structure (i.e., edges and nodes), and we assign a ±1plus-or-minus1\pm 1 tag (not labels, which will be generated later.) to each node by either manually assigning or using a Bernoulli distribution with success probability 0.50.50.5 to achieve a balance tag set. To be more specific, the hyperparameters we used to generate the graph structure are d=5,μ=0.1,λ=2.2formulae-sequence𝑑5formulae-sequence𝜇0.1𝜆2.2d=5,\mu=0.1,\lambda=2.2 and N=50𝑁50N=50. Importantly, We make sure that the entire synthetic graph is connected, and this can be easily done by selecting a slightly higher d𝑑d (average degree) and repeating the graph generation process until the generated synthetic graph is connected. Denote the tag vector as 𝒗={v​1,…,vN}∈{±1}N𝒗𝑣1…subscript𝑣𝑁superscriptplus-or-minus1𝑁{\boldsymbol{v}}=\{v1,\dots,v_{N}\}\in\{\pm 1\}^{N}. We fix the hyperparameters and graph structure, then repeat the sampling procedure for 202020 times to generate 202020 synthetic graphs that only differ in clients’ data for random experiments purposes. In a supervised classification setting, we utilize data from all clients/nodes and split the local data for each client/node into a train, validation, and test set. The feature vectors and labels in the validation test are used only for hyperparameters tuning, and the test set is used only once to calculate test accuracy. In our setting, the train-valid-test split is set to be 8.33%/8.33%/83.33%percent8.33percent8.33percent83.338.33\%/8.33\%/83.33\% (i.e., 10/10/100101010010/10/100). A relatively small data set with labels available (i.e., train and valid) for each client is reasonable to be assumed in federated learning problems, and a relatively small graph (505050 nodes) is a reasonable assumption under supervised classification tasks in real-world applications.

D.3 Model Description in Section 6

This part provides details about models used in Section 6. For training on all models, including baseline models, we use the SGD optimizer with optimized learning rates based on the specific task and models. During training, we keep tracking the lowest validation loss and the corresponding model and use this model to report test accuracy. For baseline models including GAT, GCN, and SAGE, we adapt the well-optimized original structure. However, in order to achieve a fair comparison with our method, we do not include layers like dropout on the adjacency matrix layer, no bias, and we train all baseline models using the basic SGD optimizer with an optimized learning rate instead of the Adam optimizer with weight decay (L2 regularization) which is widely used for training on these baseline models. For baseline models, including FedMLP and MLPs implemented for supervised learning tasks on synthetic graphs, we use a two-layer Multi-Layer-Perceptron (MLP) with 646464 hidden units and no bias term.

Graph Federated Learning for APPNP (GFL-APPNP). For all experiments we conduct, including deterministic node classification and stochastic node classification, we use a two-layer Multi-Layer-Perceptron (MLP) with 646464 hidden units and no bias term. We fix the teleport probability α𝛼\alpha to be 0.10.10.1 and the total steps for personalized propagation C𝐶C to be 101010, following the APPNP model in [37] and [40]. We train GFL-APPNP for different I∈1,10,20,50𝐼1102050I\in{1,10,20,50} with gradient compensation and without gradient compensation. Note that different I𝐼I will lead to different numbers of communications. For example, if we run 300030003000 updates for I=10𝐼10I=10, then the number of communications will be 3000/10=3003000103003000/10=300. For the deterministic node classification task on both synthetic graphs and subCora graphs, after optimizing the learning rate over {0.01,0.02,0.05,0.1,0.5}0.010.020.050.10.5\{0.01,0.02,0.05,0.1,0.5\}, we select 0.50.50.5 as the best learning rate for synthetic graphs and 0.020.020.02 as the best learning rate for subCora graphs. An interesting observation is that even if 0.50.50.5 is a relatively large learning rate, it works because the landscapes for the training loss on synthetic graphs are very smooth. We run 400040004000 updates for subCora graphs and 300030003000 updates for synthetic graphs. The same learning rates and the numbers of updates are adapted for both variants with gradient compensation and variants with no compensation. For the stochastic node classification task on synthetic graphs, we use a learning rate of 0.20.20.2 and a batch size of 404040 (full batch) and run 500050005000 updates for each variant with gradient compensation. For supervised classification tasks on synthetic graphs, we use a learning rate of 0.20.20.2 and batch size of 555 and run 200020002000 updates for each variant with gradient compensation.

Graph Convolutional Networks (GCN). The most common baseline is GCN originated from [41]. In our experiment, we use two GCN layers with 646464 hidden units following the well-optimized original model structure in [41]. For the deterministic node classification task on synthetic graphs, we train 400040004000 updates with a learning rate equal to 0.10.10.1. For the deterministic node classification task on subCora, we train 400040004000 updates with a learning rate equal to 0.010.010.01. These learning rates are determined by comparing the lowest validation losses.

Graph Attention Networks (GAT). Another baseline model, GAT, is conducted in our experiment following [42]. Particularly, we use 222 GAT convolutional layers where the first layer has 888 attention heads, and each head has 888 hidden units, the second layer has 111 attention head and 646464 hidden units following the well-optimized original model structure in [42]. For the deterministic node classification task on synthetic graphs, we train 400040004000 updates with a learning rate equal to 0.020.020.02. For the deterministic node classification task on subCora graphs, we train 400040004000 updates with a learning rate equal to 0.010.010.01. These learning rates are determined by comparing the lowest validation losses.

Graph Neural Networks with Sample and Aggregate (GraphSAGE). One popular GNN model we treated as a baseline is GraphSAGE which originated from [43]. In our empirical studies on deterministic node classification, we use 222 SAGE convolutional layers with 646464 hidden units. For the node classification task on synthetic graphs, we train 500050005000 updates with a learning rate equal to 0.020.020.02. For the deterministic node classification task on subCora, we train 400040004000 updates with a learning rate equal to 0.010.010.01.

Fedederated Learning for Multi-Layer-Perceptron (FedMLP). We follow a common federated learning procedure with no graph information and data sharing involved. we train this baseline model with different I∈{10,20,50}𝐼102050I\in\{10,20,50\}. For the supervised learning task on synthetic graphs, we train 200020002000 updates with a learning rate of 0.10.10.1 and a batch size of 555.

Multi-Layer-Perceptrons (MLPs). In this baseline model, each client will have one local MLP model that only utilizes its own train set for training and validation set for tuning. Each client uses the local model with the lowest validation loss calculated by its own valid set during training to report the test accuracy of its own test set. The average test accuracy across all clients is calculated and reported by the central server. For the supervised learning task on synthetic graphs, we train 200200200 updates with a learning rate of 0.10.10.1 and a batch size of 555.

D.4.3 Additional Experiment III: Necessity of Graph Structure in GFL (Figure 2)

As our discussion in Section 3, the network of clients in multi-client systems accounts for the statistical heterogeneity problem. This empirical study aims to show that the heterogeneity problem is non-negligible. Our experiment is based on the context of supervised classification with baseline models MLPs and FedMLP, matching the same setting in Section 6.3. The result is given by boxplot on Figure 2(b). The models and details are the same as Section 6.3, which can be found in Appendix D.2 and D.3.

D.4.4 Additional Experiment IV: Differential Privacy

In this section, we conduct an empirical study on DP-based Graph Federated Learning for DNC task (semi-supervised node classification) on semi-synthetic dataset subCora (See Appendix D.2. The motivation is discussed in Section 3.4. For convenience, our experiments are also called subCora DP experiments. For all subCora DP experiments, we used SGD with a learning rate of 0.010.010.01 and 400040004000 updates. We used the same model structure described in D.3. We implemented two strategies for adding noises to our method. The first one injects noise to both hidden representations and gradients, and the second one only applies noisy hidden representations. Following is the detailed description.

Noisy hidden representations(hktsuperscriptsubscriptℎ𝑘𝑡{\boldsymbol{h}}_{k}^{t}). Instead of uploading latest hidden representation 𝒉ktsuperscriptsubscript𝒉𝑘𝑡{\boldsymbol{h}}_{k}^{t} of each client k𝑘k at each communication round t𝑡t where tmodI=0modulo𝑡𝐼0t\mod I=0 to central server, we add a random noise vector denoted as ϵh,ktsuperscriptsubscriptbold-italic-ϵℎ𝑘𝑡{\boldsymbol{\epsilon}}_{h,k}^{t} that has independent standard normal entries to the hidden representation, and upload 𝒉kt+ϵh,ktsuperscriptsubscript𝒉𝑘𝑡superscriptsubscriptbold-italic-ϵℎ𝑘𝑡{\boldsymbol{h}}_{k}^{t}+{\boldsymbol{\epsilon}}_{h,k}^{t}to central server. We use different standard deviations for the noise injected in hidden representations. Figure 4 shows that when we adapt noisy hidden representations, both train and validation loss are NOT significantly affected for all standard deviations and I∈{10,20}𝐼1020I\in\{10,20\}.

Noisy hidden representations and gradients (hkt,∇hktsuperscriptsubscriptℎ𝑘𝑡∇superscriptsubscriptℎ𝑘𝑡{\boldsymbol{h}}_{k}^{t},\nabla{{\boldsymbol{h}}}_{k}^{t}). We add Gaussian noise on both hidden representations and corresponding gradients before each communication round. Formally, we inject noises ϵh,ktsuperscriptsubscriptbold-italic-ϵℎ𝑘𝑡{\boldsymbol{\epsilon}}_{h,k}^{t} and ϵg,ktsuperscriptsubscriptbold-italic-ϵ𝑔𝑘𝑡{\boldsymbol{\epsilon}}_{g,k}^{t} that has independent standard normal entries to the hidden representation and gradient vector respectively, and upload 𝒉kt+ϵh,ktsuperscriptsubscript𝒉𝑘𝑡superscriptsubscriptbold-italic-ϵℎ𝑘𝑡{\boldsymbol{h}}_{k}^{t}+{\boldsymbol{\epsilon}}_{h,k}^{t} and ∇𝒉kt+ϵg,kt∇superscriptsubscript𝒉𝑘𝑡superscriptsubscriptbold-italic-ϵ𝑔𝑘𝑡\nabla{{\boldsymbol{h}}}_{k}^{t}+{\boldsymbol{\epsilon}}_{g,k}^{t} to central server. We use different standard deviations for the noise injected in both hidden representations and corresponding gradients. Figure 5 shows that when we adapt noisy hidden representations and gradients. Noise with a relatively large standard deviation will affect the validation loss by some degree (Zoom in for better viewing quality). A larger standard deviation will result in a larger final validation loss. However, the training loss is not significantly affected. The effect of noise is more significant for larger I𝐼I.

In all plots and tables in this experiment, the label "I=10 hn0.5_gn0.5" denotes our method GFL-APPNP with I=10𝐼10I=10, and we add noises to both hidden representations and corresponding gradients with standard deviation equals 0.50.50.5. The label "I=10 hn_0.5" denotes that for our method with I=10𝐼10I=10, we add noise to hidden representations only with a standard deviation equal to 0.50.50.5. In what follows, we will use standard deviation to denote the standard deviation of the added noises.

Moreover, we also investigated the effect of the standard deviation of the noise on the test set accuracy and the effect of I𝐼I when we fix the noise strategy and standard deviation of the noise. Figure 6 shows that when we fix the noise strategy and standard deviation of the noise. A larger standard deviation for the Gaussian noise will result in worse performance (larger loss and higher variation) during training as well as validation. This matches the general situation when applying DP-based privacy-preserving strategies. Also, one can conclude that larger I𝐼I will result in a larger final validation loss which is more significant, while a larger standard deviation of the noise is applied. Figure 7 shows that in general, when we fix the noise strategy and I𝐼I, a larger standard deviation will lead to lower average test set accuracy. As one may expect, there is a trade-off between performance and privacy protection, matching the results of DP-based methods. But even with a relatively large standard deviation, the average test accuracy is still competitive compared with all other cases. This reflects that DP-based optimization is applicable under the proposed GFL setting. The exact numbers of test accuracy can be found in Table 3.
